summary: This is a service request log from August 15, 2019, detailing a priority upgrade and installation of a Nice Vision surveillance system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The work was assigned to technicians Jeff Cranor, Jeff McKenzie, and Justin Houston, with training scheduled for 'Comm Ted'.

persons.name: Jeff Cranor
persons.context: Assigned to the service request for installing a Nice Vision system at the MCC New York. Scheduled to work on-site from August 12-16, 2019.

persons.name: Jeff McKenzie
persons.context: Assigned to the service request and noted as being on-site installing the Nice Vision system at the MCC New York. Scheduled to work from August 12-16, 2019.

persons.context: Assigned to the service request for installing a Nice Vision system at the MCC New York. Scheduled to work on-site from August 12-16, 2019.

persons.context: Mentioned as the individual scheduled to receive training on the newly installed Phase 1 of the Nice Vision surveillance system the following day.

events.title: Service Request for MCC Surveillance Upgrade
events.description: A priority (P3) service request was created for the installation and upgrade of a Nice Vision surveillance system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: On-Site Installation Work Period
events.description: Technicians Jeff Cranor, Jeff McKenzie, and Justin Houston were scheduled to be on-site at the MCC New York for a multi-day installation of the new surveillance system.

events.title: Scheduled Training for MCC Staff
events.description: Training was scheduled for 'Comm Ted' on the completed Phase 1 of the new Nice Vision surveillance system installation.

keyFacts: A surveillance system (Nice Vision) was being installed at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York in August 2019.
The installation was a priority (P3) service request, indicating it required next-day attention.
The work involved installing 4 servers, 1 decoder, 12 encoders, and connecting approximately 161 cameras, with about 110 correctly named and 20 non-functional at the time of the log.
The service was contracted to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (FBOP), with technicians Jeff Cranor, Jeff McKenzie, and Justin Houston assigned to the task.
Training for MCC communications staff ('Comm Ted') was scheduled for the day after the log was created.
